discussion.content: Ans D I think is correct. You are accepted into a Group, eg 'Sales' Group which gives you Sales Group Permissions (Authorization). Ans B is Authentication.

Answer is D

Authentication vs. Authorization
What's the difference between authentication and authorization? Authentication confirms that users are who they say they are. Authorization gives those users permission to access a resource.

While authentication and authorization might sound similar, they are distinct security processes in the world of identity and access management (IAM).

What Is Authentication?
Authentication is the act of validating that users are whom they claim to be. This is the first step in any security process. 

Complete an authentication process with:

Passwords. Usernames and passwords are the most common authentication factors. If a user enters the correct data, the system assumes the identity is valid and grants access.
One-time pins. Grant access for only one session or transaction.
Authentication apps. Generate security codes via an outside party that grants access.
Biometrics. A user presents a fingerprint or eye scan to gain access to the system.
OK..maybe changed to D. After rereading it. Break B into two parts and it fails. So D it is
B makes sense to me. Authorization

What is the primary different between AAA authentication and authorization? A. Authentication verifies a username and password, and authorization handles the communication between the authentication agent and the user database.

Definition per CompTIA guide: 
Authorization—determining what rights subjects should have on each resource, and enforcing those rights.
The answer D seems the most appropriate out of all.
what it seems to me is one time passwords are authentication which is the first A in AAA but the question is asking for the second A which is authorization so D looks correct

other sites have B as an answer and it makes sense. The second A is Authorization and what better explanation can be given to authorization than giving access after entering a password? I can see why ppl may chose D but I think the BEST answer is B. loophole please provide proof instead of simply saying don't believe someone else's comments.

questions.question_text: Which of the following threat actors is motivated primarily by a desire for personal recognition and a sense of accomplishment?

discussion.content: Take away here is "running access level" if someone have an access to a system, that means they must have use some sort of credential to access the system. Therefore, the answer is CREDENTIALED SCAN

A credentialed scan gives you much more information, because you are able to access more information and configuration details about a system when logged in with valid privileged credentials than you would if you used a non-credentialed scan.
Mike Meyer’s CompTIA Security+ p. 495
"access level" - A
Answer is A. Keyword "access level"
emphasis on 'better assess vulnerabilities' that makes it CREDENTIALED SCAN. it gives more details which makes it better
You got that right Sunmmy
Why not C? Service access could be even without credentials..

questions.question_text: A vulnerability scanner that uses its running service's access level to better assess vulnerabilities across multiple assets within an organization is performing a:

An attacker has gained control of several systems on the Internet and is using them to attack a website, causing it to stop responding to legitimate traffic. Which of the following BEST describes the attack?

discussion.content:
D is correct 
DDoS attack is where multiple systems target a single system with a DoS attack (coming from multiple IP addresses)

choices.C: Implementing time-of-day restrictions based on location
choices.B: Adding location to the standard naming convention
choices.D: Conducting regular account maintenance at each location

questions.question_text:
A company has users and printers in multiple geographic locations, and the printers are located in common areas of the offices. To preserve the confidentiality of
PII, a security administrator needs to implement the appropriate controls. Which of the following would BEST meet the confidentiality requirements of the data?

discussion.content:
A. Enforcing location-based policy restrictions - Location-based policies are also often used as a part of Network Access Control (NAC) to determine whether access to the network itself should be granted. certain areas you can printer to and others is a no no. ..
B. Adding location to the standard naming convention - this doesn't help with PII
C. Implementing time-of-day restrictions based on location - this could cause problems or interfere if restricted to login during certain hours. 
D. Conducting regular account maintenance at each location - does nothing to provide confidentiality 
I pick A... looks right to me.. easy....just this one.. a lot of the questions suck...

to protect against identifying PII, standard company naming conventions need to be enforced and by adding string to ordinary naming schemes makes it even more difficult for non-company entities to identify naming patterns. From proff messer changing names of employees to employee Ids or other non identifiable naming schemes protect PII
